ratings.comment: Prof. Viaclovsky is definitely one of the better math instructors in the department. His lectures were very clear and straight forward compared to other courses I have taken in the Math Department.

Material is easy, but small mistakes on tests/quizzes can severely impact your grade. If you do get an A, it will come with a lot of stress.  It's easy to learn from the book, and his lectures only make sense if you read ahead. It's tempting to skip lecture, but we were occasionally tested on material not in the book.  Would not recommend

The content of this course is not hard. Easy to get an A but also easy to lose that chance. It is not curved and you have to hand in the HW every week or else you lose points. Also, partial credit is rarely given. I was sure I was going to get an A in this course, since all my exam grades were above 90, but my final grade was way below that.

Avoid if at all possible. He's a very poor lecturer; very mumbly and lessons dont  make sense unless you've already taught yourself some of it.   The material itself is actually pretty simple but he has very strict grading criteria with no curve, making it difficult to get a good grade.

I got average grade for first midterm, 91 for second and 98 for the last midterm and still got a B. I asked the TA and he said AB was given only to people with 89% and my score is 88.58%. How could this happen? I feel like I am actually curved down and not being rewarded for making the effort along the way. Should have given a bad evaluation.

I had Jeff for both math 234 and math 320, and both semesters I thought he was a fair teacher, especially for 320. He knows the material well and structures the lectures based off the book. The exams are just like the HW, so they are pretty straight forward if you take the time to do the HW. He also omits unnecessary proofs which is a plus

Overall, Jeff's teaching style was very effective. In lecture, there were very few pointless proofs, and he covered examples that mirrored homework problems. If you could do the homework, the tests were no  problem. Would very much recommend Jeff as a professor.

While Jeff can be a little monotone in his delivery, he can have a nice dry sense of humor, and more often than not HE CUTS OUT UNNECESSARY PROOFS!  His tests aren't tough, as long as you do the homework.

234 is a tough class but I really liked Jeff. I thought his exams were fair and if you knew the material you could do well. Make sure to do homework! He's a quirky guy and he liked to make jokes in class which made it much more bearable. I think his lectures were clear and relatively easy to follow considering the material.

Assigns reasonable amounts of homework while cutting out junk problems. Quizzes and tests are based closely on this. It's not graded, but doing it is a huge help!  Lectures only make sense if you know the content. If you know the content, lectures are unnecessary.  Humor is sparse, but the joke is enhanced by the monotone delivery and surprise.

Jeff speaks monotonously during his lectures, which may cause drowsiness in some. His tests are unbelievably difficult and almost beyond the scope of what he teaches in lectures. His class was also entirely test based so good luck. If you see his name on your schedule for the semester, I would recommend attempting to switch professors.

Jeff is obviously very knowledgeable in the subject, but would frequently mumble and come to unclear conclusions in lecture and leave students (including me) wondering what happened and needing to do a lot of work outside of class. He follows the packet almost exactly, which can be nice, but the tests deviate from this and are very difficult.

Hardest class I've ever take. I went to lecture to find out what I needed to know not to learn. Jeff is a pretty good professor, but it was my TA who helped me the grade that I did.   However, I would recommend this professor over the alternatives. I would choose Dr. V again.

The tests were pretty easy but you need to find another way to learn the material because Jeff does a pretty bad job at teaching it (using a lot of proofs in the beginning). Pray for a good TA to carry you through the course.  He looks like Taco from The League

At first, I wanted to change my major because I just couldn't understand class. Both midterms were easy and the final was fair as well. Homework wasn't required which screwed me over because I didn't do it at first. DO HOMEWORK, at least some of it. It does help. Jeff is a really funny guy. Go to his office hours just because. Class is worth it.

After a rough start, Dr. Jeff seemed to change things up. After the first test, He slowed things down and did fewer proofs and more examples. Not the best educator I've met, but he deserves more than the mid-semester raters have given him. After two easy midterms, the final was surprisingly hard. The bell curve stretched from 0% to 100%.

I think professor Jeff is one of the best professors that I have ever met because he always explains everything clearly. If you can attend every lectures and one of  review sessions, you will get an easy A.

This is my second calculus class at UW so i'm mostly comparing him with another professor. Simply put, if you think you're good enough at math to learn by yourself then you should definitely take his class,  his exams are straightforward with no tricky questions. But if you need someone to teach you, definitely  look elsewhere.

From what I've heard from students in other Calc class, Jeff seems like the best. He's fluent in english and the tests are really straight forward, although they can be a little tough. If you have to take 234, try to get into his class.

Personally, I loved Dr. V. Straight forward lecturer with fair exams. He always had a review session the lecture before where he would outline what would be on the test. They were tough, but he rarely threw a curveball at us. Also, his attempts at jokes are usually good for a laugh.  I would definitely take another course with him, great professor.

As a teacher he needs a lot of improvement and needs to rely on sources other than the book as his lectures consist of him just repeating what is already in there. As a grader, I've had worse but he's still pretty bad because he doesn't really cube exams in the usual way. My advice: if you can choose another instructor you should definitely do so.
Probably the worst instructor I've had. His grading is fair though. But he doesn't curve exams. If you have to take his class, pray for a good TA or find a good book.

Jeff started out a little rocky because it was his first time teaching but once he got more comfortable and used more examples he was an effective lecturer. The tests are fair and straight forward and he prepares you for them well. Pretty funny too

He is so much more helpful during office hours. For his lectures, make sure you follow EVERY SINGLE THING he says, otherwise you're going to get left behind. Cracks jokes so bad they make people laugh. Again, visit him during office hours!

He is good,  sometimes funny in lectures. However, he started becoming funny only 2 weeks before student's evaluations. I think you know what I mean. He cares only about himself taking good evals from students. Exams are faireasy. The textbook is not perfect, but still better than the one of 221.
The homework is not mandatory, but it's very helpful, a fair grader and the exams are not so hard.

I think he is very good professor overall. At the beginning of the semester he wasn't so good at all, but later he became organized and he seemed to care more about his students. Exams are pretty fair. Compared to other math professors he is definitely above average! With reasonable amount of work you can get an A-B.

As a first year student, Jeff was my first actual college math professor. Overall, he explained the topics very clearly even though it was straight out of the book. He did plenty of examples to clarify the concepts and his tests reflected what we did in lecture. Compared to what I've heard about other profs, he seems like one of the better ones.

As math profs go he is the best I've had so far. He's a little scatterbrained and is weirdly sassy, but his lectures are strait forward and to the point. There are moments when he is confusing which is why it was nice to have a good TA but he was a good professor and he taught the material well.

Jeff is really brilliant at math, but cannot teach multivariable calculus. His lectures are straight out of the course packet, even the examples. I skipped lecture between the first and second exam, just reading the course packet and watching MITs youtube videos instead and my exam score improvemed. All of the exam questions are right from homework

The lectures sometimes seem pointless when I'm sitting in them but if you don't attend you WILL fall behind. Took this class as my first math class of college and was completely unprepared with how tough it was. I put in hard work and still felt overwhelmed on the exams. If you're a freshman reading this expect to be doing a lot of work.

He's a good teacher who gives very straightforward and fair exams that are completely doable and almost easy if you actually study and know the material. Early on in the semester, he wasn't that good in lectures, but has gotten much better and his lectures are now useful. A bit of a jokester as well.

You can tell Jeff is great at math.  A genius with it sometimes but when it comes to teaching that is something he needs work on. All about proofs. Your TA will make a huge difference on your knowledge of the subject.

Some people didn't like grading but I thought exams were very fair. It was very proof heavy at first but he does a lot of examples now in class which are very helpful. He's kinda weird but that makes class hilarious.

Teaches out of the course packet. I learned more from five minutes of MIT OCW's multivariable calculus course than a week of his lectures. Everything you learn in the lecture you probably won't need for the exam. He has a good sense of humor, and he's a nice guy, just not the best prof. Get a real calculus textbook and burn the course packet.

He may be a little dry and proof-heavy in lecture, but overall he covers everything pretty well, is happy to help his students, and is clear about what will be on the exam. The exams are presented fairly so don't expect to see any terrible surprises.

He IS a good math professor. You can do well if you take the time to do the homework assigned. If you're not willing to work hard, then you shouldn't take this class with him.  I pretty much got an A on everything and that's just because I took the time to go over things a little bit each day. This calculus course is easier than the others.
He makes even the easiest things seem like the most difficult thing in the world. He lives in his own world.

TERRIBLE do not take his class. Jeff can't explain anything well, and all he does are proofs, no examples of how to use equations. There's nothing you can take out from his lecture. Better to not even attend and read course packet. No difference there.
He doesn't reply to any emails at all and he is not helpful at office hours too. He doesn't explain anything and if you ask him he just says something even more complicated.

The Professor just lives in his own research world. His lectures are really confusing and often off the topic a little. He has NEVER   explained topics explicitly to the students. I found that I have to revise all the stuff and his notes are really confusing and helpless to me.

AVOID Jeff Viaclovsky AT ALL COSTS! He is the worst professor I have ever heard of. He teaches topic in the most confusing way possible. I had trouble trying to follow what he was trying to teach since he wrote so fast! What he taught did not match the textbook but is in the exam range. OMG!!!

His lecture is like doing his own research and nobody knows what he is talking about. It is only good because of no homework to hand-in but you hardly have idea of how to do it unless you learn yourself. His office hour doesn't work for most of the students...lol. Try it and Feel(Fail) it.

Would NOT recommend!  He just talks into the board the whole time.  Doesn't explain anything that gets written down, plus the lectures are just him copying the textbook onto the board. NO EXAMPLES!! His pace is way too fast, so you can't process anything that is said during lecture.  You can only hope to frantically copy everything down in time.

The professor just put all the notes which was the paraphrase of our textbook on the blackboard with a little bit explanation. He writes so fast  that I can hardly catch up . You have to learn by yourself!  His lecture is useless. I will never recommend you guys to take this course!!!
Great professor, he's easily one of the better math professors on campus.  His lectures are actually helpful to attend which was refreshing.
